occurrences.line_text: The daughter of great Nereus, which did beare
They easily vnto her charet beare:
And strow with flowres the lamentable beare:
For both the boughes doe laughing blossomes beare,
From perill free he her away did beare:
Like as a Goshauke, that in foote doth beare
Dy, if thou it gainesay: I will away her beare.
Besought them humbly, him to beare withal,
The which she meant away with her to beare;
For loe that Guest would beare her forcibly,
Which all good knights, that armes do beare this day,
I pardon yield, and with thy rudenesse beare;
He ran as fast, as both his feete could beare,
Ne scarsely who before: like as a Beare
For he the powre of chast hands might not beare,
Ne in that stownd wist, how her selfe to beare;
Yet both in flowres do liue, and loue thee beare,
Whom Ioue did loue, and chose his cup to beare,
And in his hand a windy fan did beare,
And outward shew faire semblance they did beare;
Like as a gloomie cloud, the which doth beare
Too boastfull Blandamour, too long I beare
Did beare them both to fell auenges end,
And gan therefore close spight to him to beare:
Were sent, that seemed death in them to beare,
That horse and man to ground he quite did beare,
So Satyrane that day was iudg'd to beare the bell.
The which this famous Britomart did beare;
And wiuehood true, to all that did it beare;
For pearelesse she was thought, that did it beare.
For that with puissant stroke she downe did beare
That she should surely beare the bell away,
But some celestiall shape, that flesh did beare:
With which he all that met him, downe did beare.
The which from him his fairest loue did beare.
Then she, ne vnto whom I more true loue did beare.
That yet of mortall stroke the stound doth beare.
And now he her away with him did beare
Yet he his hand so carefully did beare,
For bootlesse thing it was to think such blowes to beare.
And with her dolefull accent beare with him apart.
And on his warlike beast them both did beare,
The burden of the deadly brunt did beare
That seemed nought the souse thereof could beare,
Which I to him as to my soule did beare;
To guide the beast, that did his maister beare,
And taking leaue of all, with him did beare
Yet did those two them selues so brauely beare,
And lay on load, as they him downe would beare;
And that huge Riuer, which doth beare his name
And with him beare, where none of her might know.
And though his limbs could not his bodie beare,
And on his steed her set, to beare her out of sight.
Beare for his penaunce that same Ladies head;
He chose with shame to beare that Ladies head
And with it beare the burden of defame;
To beare that Ladies head before his breast.
He tooke it vp, and thence with him did beare,
His puissance, ne beare him selfe vpright,
He could no longer beare, but forth issewed,
That shield, which thou doest beare, was it indeed,
And this the arme, the which that shield did beare,
He askt, what priuie tokens he did beare.
As when a Beare hath seiz'd her cruell clawes
And beare with you both wine and iuncates fit,
And like a greedie Beare vnto her pray,
Beare off the burden of her raging yre;
It is no lesse beseeming well, to beare
I will a while with his first folly beare,
To beare vnto her loue the message of her mind.
Th'one from the earth, & through the aire doth beare;
And afterwards a sonne to him shalt beare,
And thus vpbrayding sayd; This token beare
And his wingfooted coursers him did beare
Fast did they fly, as them their feete could beare,
Did beare the pendants, through their nimblesse bold:
And made it beare the yoke of inquisition,
But th'Adamantine shield, which he did beare,
And in his hand an huge Polaxe did beare,
As Curtesie, to beare themselues aright
Of many a Lyon, and of many a Beare
Which I enforst to beare though to my paine,
Fellow of this I beare, throwne not in vaine,
Of all which I yet glad to beare the packe,
Which to thy noble personage I beare,
Of him, that did the kingly Scepter beare,
I may beare armes, and learne to vse them right;
And for the courteous care, which he did beare
And him to beare, she thought it thing too base.
To beare this burden on your dainty backe;
My selfe will beare a part, coportion of your packe.
Vpon the ground, like to an hollow beare;
And twixt them both with parted paines did beare,
With bleeding wounds, brought home vpon a Beare
And by outragious force away did beare:
If I would beare behinde a burden of such scorne.
Or beare her on thy backe with pleasing payne,
And whylest an Infant from a Beare
For from his mothers wombe, which him did beare
A cruell Beare, the which an infant bore
So well he sped him, that the wearie Beare
Beare off their blowes, from percing thorough quite.
Aboue a launces length him forth did beare,
And could no lenger beare so great abuse,
Till they him force the buxome yoke to beare:
But all that leg, which did his body beare,
But tell me Lady, wherefore doe you beare
And of the pray each one a part doth beare.
Aboue all other lasses beare the bell,
And fared like a furious wyld Beare,
Beares her away vpon his courser light:
Whose shield he beares renuerst, the more to heape disdayn.
Yea but (quoth she) he beares a charmed shield,
And with her beares the fowle welfauourd witch:
And from the she Beares teats her whelps to teare;
The other like a Beares vneuen paw:
From highest heauen, and beares an equall eye?
The godly Matrone by the hand him beares
So boldly he him beares, and rusheth forth
Them on her bulwarke beares, and bids them nought auaile.
Saue Beares, Lions, & Buls, which romed them around.
Beares he himselfe with portly maiestee,
And reach into the house, that beares the stile
Beares in his boasted fan, or Iris bright,
Made of Beares skin, that him more dreadfull made,
I wote not well, but in his shield he beares
With Beares and Tygers taking heauie part,
Was hunting then the Libbards and the Beares,
For other food then that wilde forrest beares,
That could haue perst the hearts of Tigres & of Beares.
As that same other Isle, that greater bredth now beares.
Of Beares and Tygres, nor so saluage mynded,
And some of Beares, that groynd continually,
And beareth fruit of honour and all chast desire.
Or wearied with bearing of her bag
And bearing with him treasure in close store,
Bearing that precious relicke in an arke
He stayed not, but in his armes her bearing
Bearing a litle Dwarfe before his steed,
Bearing the shield which I had conquerd late,
Bearing his sixe deformed heads on hye,
Quartred athwart, and bearing in his targe
Into the wood was bearing her apace
The trustie damzell bearing it abrode
Which now thou bear'st, to thee descended farre
As her slow beast could make; but all in vaine:
From her vnhastie beast she did alight,
The Lyon Lord of euerie beast in field,
The kingly beast vpon her gazing stood;
And entring is; when that disdainfull beast
Of saluage beast, his puissance to withstand:
Her seruile beast yet would not leaue her so,
And all the way, most like a brutish beast,
And chase the saluage beast with busie payne,
That euery beast for feare of him did fly and quake.
And there abode, whilst any beast of name
A monstrous beast ybred in filthy fen
Vpon this dreadfull Beast with seuenfold head
Who slayes the Gyant, wounds the beast,
High mounted on her manyheaded beast,
Her dreadfull beast, who swolne with bloud of late
Enforst her purple beast with all her might
So downe he fell before the cruell beast,
And to the beast gan turne his enterprise;
And eke the fruitfull-headed beast, amaz'd
By this the dreadfull Beast drew nigh to hand,
The wrathfull beast about him turned light,
Exceeding rage enflam'd the furious beast,
The beast impatient of his smarting wound,
The hell-bred beast threw forth vnto the skyes,
For nigh thereto the euer damned beast
Who thereby dead that balefull Beast did deeme,
Reioycing at the fall of that great beast,
In case he could that monstrous beast destroy,
Such wounded beast, as that, I did not see,
In mind to marke the beast. At which sad stowre,
The truncked beast fast bleeding, did him fowly dight.
To wreake it selfe on beast all innocent,
He slips aside; the whiles that furious beast
Ne man nor beast may rest, or take repast,
His Beast he felly prickt on either syde,
His light-foot beast, fled fast away for feare:
To be a beast, and lacke intelligence.
The saluage beast embost in wearie chace,
To hunt the saluage beast in forrest wyde,
That lou'd a Bull, and learnd a beast to bee;
That euen the wild beast shall dy in starued den.
There she alighted from her light-foot beast,
Whether through swiftnesse of his speedy beast,
Of some wild beast, which with her arrowes keene
Well hoped she the beast engor'd had beene,
And thereby deemd the beast had bene depriu'd
That hath escaped from a rauenous beast,
An hideous beast, of horrible aspect,
Vpon the beast, that with great cruelty
And with it bound the beast, that lowd did rore
Thus as he led the Beast along the way,
He left his captiue Beast at liberty,
Where late he left the Beast, he ouercame,
Now when the Beast, which by her wicked art
T'haue seene, (quoth he) when as a monstrous beast
That euery bird and beast awarned made,
That man and beast with powre imperious
The beast astonisht stands in middest of his smart.
His neather lip was not like man nor beast,
And on his warlike beast them both did beare,
Vpon his vsuall beast it firmely bound,
To guide the beast, that did his maister beare,
The tast of bloud of some engored beast,
Bound like a beast appointed to the stall:
Vppon the carkasse of some beast too weake,
To heare the piteous beast pleading her plaintiffe cause.
Warn'd man and beast in quiet rest be shrowded,
And earely calling forth both man and beast,
But putting spurres vnto her fiery beast,
That she to hunt the beast first tooke in hond;
On man and beast, that commeth in her path.
An huge great Beast it was, when it in length
Both man and beast doe fly, and succour doe inquyre.
A monster, which the Blatant beast men call,
Thereto the Blatant beast by them set on
The Blattant Beast (quoth he) I doe pursew,
What is that Blattant Beast? (then he replide)
Sayd Artegall, I such a Beast did see,
That surely is that Beast (saide Calidore)
Pursues the Blatant Beast:
The Blatant Beast forth rushing vnaware,
The Beast with their pursuit incited more,
Ne fed on flesh, ne euer of wyld beast
Wherewith the beast enrag'd to loose his pray,
The Blatant Beast the fittest meanes they found,
They sent that Blatant Beast to be a baite,
That no one beast in forrest wylde or tame,
Of their late woundes, the which the Blatant Beast
Such were the wounds, the which that Blatant Beast
For that same beast was bred of hellish strene,
This hellish Dog, that hight the Blatant Beast;
And eke the biting of that harmefull Beast
The whiles the beast doth rage and loudly rore,
Sewing the Blatant beast, which I forbore
If such a beast they saw, which he had thether brought.
They answer'd him, that no such beast they saw,
Who now does follow the foule Blatant Beast,
When he the beast saw ready now to rend
Do seize vpon some beast, whose flesh is bare,
Calidore doth the Blatant beast
To his atchieuement of the Blatant beast;
That monstrous Beast by finall force to quell,
Were yrkesome to report; yet that foule Beast
Full cruelly the Beast did rage and rore,
Such was the fury of this hellish Beast,
Tho when the Beast saw, he mote nought auaile,
Yet greatly did the Beast repine at those
To see him leade that Beast in bondage strong,
And much admyr'd the Beast, but more admyr'd the Knight.
The saluage beastes in her victorious play,
Of fowles and beastes he made the piteous prayes,
Hath tracted forth some saluage beastes trade;
Then Guyon askt, what meant those beastes, which there did ly.
Do lay away, and all wilde beastes do rest,
Then of wilde beastes if she had chased beene:
Least saluage beastes her person haue despoyld:
Nor bands of nature, that wilde beastes restraine,
Amongst wilde beastes in desert forrests bred,
For that beastes teeth, which wounded you tofore,
Ne mote wylde beastes, ne mote the ruder clowne
Inglorious and beastlike is: therefore Sir knight,
That their owne mother loathd their beastlinesse,
And all attonce her beastly body raizd
Thensforth from her most beastly companie
More mild in beastly kind, then that her beastly foe.
More mild in beastly kind, then that her beastly foe.
With beastly sin thought her to haue defilde,
And burnt his beastly hart t'efforce her chastitye.
And made her person thrall vnto his beastly kind.
He loudly brayd with beastly yelling sound,
With beastly brutish rage gan him assay,
Of hideous Giants, and halfe beastly men,
Said Guyon, See the mind of beastly man,
Breathing out beastly lust her to defile:
No loue, but brutish lust, that was so beastly tind.
Beastly he threw her downe, ne car'd to spill
In beastly vse that I did euer find;
Thereof by force to take their beastly pleasure.
But this was drawne of six vnequall beasts,
Like carkases of beasts in butchers stall.
Emongst wild beasts and woods, from lawes of men exilde.
The angry beasts not rashly to despise,
Wyld beasts in yron yokes he would compell;
Whose face he made, all beasts to feare, and gaue
The wood is fit for beasts, the court is fit for thee.
Of men, then beasts. But ï¿½ th'exceeding grace
But like wild beasts lurking in loathsome den,
A man, of many partes from beasts deriued,
Of many beasts, that roard outrageously,
Vntill they came in vew of those wild beasts:
As those vnruly beasts to hold without;
Said he, These seeming beasts are men indeed,
And streight of beasts they comely men became;
From chase of greater beasts, whose brutish pryde
Your glory set, to chace the saluage beasts,
Some made for beasts, some made for birds to weare,
Nor wicked beasts their tender buds did crop,
Thereto so swift, that it all beasts did pas:
And suffred beasts her body to deflowre:
In power of herbes, and tunes of beasts and burds;
Haue by good fortune found some beasts fresh spoyle,
That all brute beasts forst to refraine fro meat,
Of men and beasts; and fed on fleshly gore,
Of beasts, or of the earth, I haue not red:
Then doe the saluage beasts begin to play
Peace vniuersall rayn'd mongst men and beasts,
Vpon wyld beasts, which she in woods did find,
That euen wilde beasts did feare his awfull sight,
That shortly did all other beasts subdew.
Their bodies to his beasts for prouender did spred.
But mongst wyld beasts and saluage woods to dwell;
Nor none but beasts may be of her despoyled:
For beasts and foules to feede vpon for their repast.
Ne scarse wyld beasts durst come, there was this wights abode.
Least that the beasts sharpe teeth had any wound
Mongst saluage beasts, both rudely borne and bred,
The whyles their beasts there in the budded broomes
And beat their brests, and naked flesh to teare.
Both stricken strike, and beaten both do beat,
With which whenas him list the ayre to beat,
The rolling billowes beat the ragged shore,
And being downe the villein sore did beat,
Why do thy cruell billowes beat so strong,
When the bright sunne his beams thereon doth beat;
The roring billowes beat his bowre so boystrously.
Did beat and bounse his head and brest full sore;
And with wide wings to beat the buxome ayre,
So dreadfully he did the anduile beat,
And beat his breast vnworthy of such blame,
And either beat him in, or driue him out.
And with their boughes the gentle plants did beat.
Else he doth hold him backe or beat away.
And with their might beat downe licentious lust,
Did beat vppon the gates to enter in,
With his great yron sledge doth strongly on it beat.
Doth beat vpon the gentle bird in vaine,
But that the Goddesse with her rod him backe did beat.
But he the bush did beat, till that at last
For soone as he their outrage backe doth beat,
And lends vnto it leaue the emptie ayre to beat.
About her eares, does beat her brest, & forhead knockes.
That menaced me from the field to beat,
And beat her breast, and piteously her selfe torment.
On euery side, and beat about him round;
And beat them back, whilest many vnderneath him fell.
Traceth his ground, and round about doth beat,
The more they him misust, and cruelly did beat.
See how they doe that Squire beat and reuile;
That he his face, his head, his brest did beat,
And rather did the more her beate and bruse.
As such a Lady so to beate and bruse;
That path they take, that beaten seemd most bare,
That path he kept, which beaten was most plaine,
Much like, as when the beaten marinere,
He leaues the welkin way most beaten plaine,
Both stricken strike, and beaten both do beat,
Through which a beaten broad high way did trace,
To a broad gate, all built of beaten gold:
Through griesly shadowes by a beaten path,
And led him to the Castle by the beaten way.
Her garments all were wrought of beaten gold,
But beaten were, and chased all about.
Beaten with stones downe from the battilment,
To rest my barcke, which hath bene beaten late
Conuerting, forth she beates the dustie path;
Beates downe both leaues and buds without regard,
She doth support, and strongly beateth downe
Did alwayes sore, beating his yron wings;
And feeling by his pulses beating rife,
And beating downe, what euer nigh him came,
Of many yron hammers beating ranke,
And oft to grone with billowes beating from the maine.
Yet loe the seas I see by often beating,
Whilest thus amidst the billowes beating of her
She thus oft times was beating off and on,
Now beating his hard head vpon a stone,
From his Beauperes, and from bright heauens vew,
And she her selfe of beautie soueraigne Queene,
Whose borrowed beautie now appeareth plaine
Then beautie brought t'vnworthy wretchednesse
O how can beautie maister the most strong,
Yet her bright blazing beautie did assay
He all his Peeres in beautie did surpas,
Then gan her beautie shine, as brightest skye,
All stand astonied at her beautie bright,
And wonder of her beautie soueraine,
That flowre of faith and beautie excellent.
Wherewith her heauenly beautie she did hide,
And marre the blossome of your beautie bright:
And borrow'd beautie spoyld. Her nathelesse
For feare through want of skill her beautie to disgrace?
And with her wondrous beautie rauisht quight,
Thus lowly to abase thy beautie bright,
One boastes her beautie, and does yeeld to vew
And his fraile eye with spoyle of beautie feedes;
Of wondrous beautie, and of freshest yeares,
But if the beautie of her mind ye knew,
And your faire beautie do with sadnesse spill?
Doth florish in all beautie excellent:
Beautie, and money, they that Bulwarke sorely rent.
Of their proud beautie, and th'one moyity
In picturing the parts of beautie daint,
Whose soueraine beautie hath no liuing pere,
When first her tender hart was with his beautie smit.
And of rare beautie, sauing that askaunce
Such was the beautie and the shining ray,
Defast the beautie of the shining sky,
But that sweet fit, that doth true beautie loue,
Whom late in chace of beautie excellent
The beautie of his worke? Indeed in sleepe
The goodly ornaments of beautie bright;
The whiles her matchlesse beautie him dismayd.
Faire ympes of beautie, whose bright shining beames
That shall embellish more your beautie bright,
And both encreast her beautie excellent;
Of bountie, and of beautie, and all vertues rare.
Features of beautie, and all shapes select,
And that faire flowre of beautie fades away,
Of grace and beautie noble Paragone,
That beautie durst presume to violate,
Faire Helene, flowre of beautie excellent,
Of rare aspect, and beautie without peare;
Wherewith the worlds faire beautie she hath blent:
For vnder maske of beautie and good grace,
To sell her borrowed beautie to abuse.
The snowy Florimell, whose beautie bright
After each beautie, that appeard in sight,
And with her beautie bountie did compare,
The prize of her, which did in beautie most excell.
Whose beautie each of them thought excellent,
To be the prize of beautie and of might;
The prize of beautie still hath ioyned beene;
And passing beautie did eftsoones reueale,
Who with her forged beautie did seduce
And to the Queene of beautie close did call,
Then beautie, which was made to represent
For most of strength and beautie his desire
And were her vertue like her beautie bright,
The Queene of beautie, and of loue the mother,
But it in shape and beautie did excell
Great Venus, Queene of beautie and of grace,
That glorious spoyle of beautie with me lead,
Admyr'd her beautie much, as she mote well:
But ruth of beautie will it mollifie.
Yet did appeare rare beautie in her face,
To blot your beautie, that vnblemisht is,
For beautie is more glorious bright and clere,
Did boast her beautie had such soueraine might,
Whether in beauties glorie did exceede;
Dimmed her former beauties shining ray,
And boasts, in beauties chaine not to be bound,
The blazing brightnesse of her beauties beame,
Inflamed was to follow beauties chace,
That her broad beauties beam great brightnes threw
Would not so lightly follow beauties chace,
Or quite deuourd her beauties scornefull grace.
But when he saw that blazing beauties beame,
Where beauties prize shold win that pretious spoyle:
The controuerse of beauties soueraine grace;
Of beauties praise, and yeeld the fayrest her due fee.
Whose beauties beame eftsoones did shine so bright,
For Chian folke to pourtraict beauties Queene,
For that strange Dame, whose beauties wonderment
To doe to so diuine a beauties excellence.
Had left that Turneyment for beauties prise,
And purchased this peerelesse beauties spoile,
Shyning with beauties light, and heauenly vertues grace.
The semblant of this false by his faire beauties Queene.
Of both their beauties to make paragone,
As beauties louely baite, that doth procure
Adornd with goodly gifts of beauties grace,
Ne ought in all that world of beauties rare,
Whether it were the traine of beauties Queene,
Which with their presence faire, the place much beautifide.
Mantled with greene, and goodly beautifide
With such an one was Thamis beautifide;
So made by art, to beautifie the rest,
Each did the others worke more beautifie;
Wherewith dame Nature doth her beautifie,
Which with rare light his bote did beautifie,
Which doe the earth enrich and beautifie:
And beautifull, as glories beames appeare,
Wherewith the Craftesman wonts it beautify,
And Clare, and Harwitch both doth beautify:
Whose forged beauty he did take in hand,
Of wondrous beauty, and of bountie rare,
So shamelesse beauty soone becomes a loathy sight.
T'adore thing so diuine as beauty, were but right.
Whose beauty doth her bounty far surpasse,
With wonder of her beauty fed their hungry vew.
And eke the famous prize of beauty from them wonne.
Of beauty gan to bud, and bloosme delight,
Such was the beauty of this goodly band,
Seem'd all the rest in beauty to excell,
